description: two shirtless men climbing a tall pole, with another shirtless man bending to put his hands in a pot at LLC and a fourth shirtless man at bottom center watching climbers; woman with a dark blouse, seen from back, LRC; people looking out windows of four-story building in background; crowd on street in middle ground
inscription:
Signature, Title, Inscription and Stamp

LRC, in pencil: [Tir. (?) 25 E (?)]; URC, in black ink: [L.B.22]; on back, in pencil: [661], [01.1.25], [002235] and [Un 14 Juillet, Rue Galande, Le Mât de Cocagne]; see Signed
markings: LRC of image, stamped in red: [AL]; LRC of sheet, stamped in black: [RMx]
medium: Etching and aquatint on Japanese-style paper
provenance: Estate of Auguste Lèpere (Lugt 141). Roger Marx, Lugt 2229 (1859-1913), Paris. [Eric G. Carlson Fine Prints and Drawings, New York, until 2008; sold in August for PLTO, to Drake]; Harry Drake, St. Paul (2008-d. 2012; bequeathed to MIA)
text: Bastille Day is July 14 in France, and is similar to Independence Day, on July 4, in the United States. Both are days when festivities can outpace recollections of historical events. Here, neighborhood boys strip down and attempt to climb a greased pole in hopes of grabbing a sausage or a sweet suspended from a wagon wheel. The Rue Galande of the print’s title is one of the oldest streets on the Left Bank (south side) of the River Seine. Home to some of the city’s poorer residents, this area was an object of fascination for middle- and upper-class Parisians in the late 1800s. Those too timid to visit these neighborhoods in person could experience them through prints like this one.
title: Bastille Day on Rue Galande
